The student exerts a constant horizontal force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> over the time interval from time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> while pushing the disk. i. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="F sub H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Assume there is negligible friction between the student’s shoes and the surface. After time <math alttext="t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student slides with speed <math alttext="v sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Derive an equation for the ratio <math alttext="v sub D, end sub, divided by v sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

(a) A student of mass <math alttext="M sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, standing on a smooth surface, uses a stick to push a disk of mass <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student exerts a constant horizontal force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> over the time interval from time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> while pushing the disk. Assume there is negligible friction between the disk and the surface.

i. Assuming the disk begins at rest, determine an expression for the final speed <math alttext="v sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk relative to the surface. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="F sub H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Assume there is negligible friction between the student’s shoes and the surface. After time <math alttext="t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student slides with speed <math alttext="v sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Derive an equation for the ratio <math alttext="v sub D, end sub, divided by v sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) Assume that the student’s mass is greater than that of the disk <math alttext="M sub S, is greater than M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the grid below, sketch graphs of the speeds of both the student and the disk as functions of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals 2 times t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that neither the disk nor the student collides with anything after <math alttext="t sub t sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the vertical axis, label <math alttext="v sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="v sub S" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>. Label the graphs “<math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>” and “<math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>” for the student and the disk, respectively.

(c) The disk is now moving at a constant speed <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> on the surface toward a block of mass <math alttext="M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is at rest on the surface, as shown above. The disk and block collide head-on and stick together, and the center of mass of the disk-block system moves with speed <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

i. Suppose the mass of the disk is much greater than the mass of the block. Estimate the velocity of the center of mass of the disk-block system. Explain how you arrived at your prediction without deriving it mathematically.

ii. Suppose the mass of the disk is much less than the mass of the block. Estimate the velocity of the center of mass of the disk-block system. Explain how you arrived at your prediction without deriving it mathematically.

iii. Now suppose that neither object's mass is much greater than the other but that they are not necessarily equal. Derive an equation for <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

iv. Consider the scenario from part (c)(i), where the mass of the disk was much greater than the mass of the block. Does your equation for <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from part (c)(iii) agree with your reasoning from part (c)(i) ?

____ Yes          ____ No

Explain your reasoning by addressing why, according to your equation, <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> becomes (or approaches) a certain value when <math alttext="M sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is much greater than <math alttext="M sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
